title: Gnome With the Wand of Death
data:
In *NetHack*, [intelligent monsters](/wiki/Intelligent_monster "Intelligent monster") can make use of attack [wands](/wiki/Wand "Wand"); this includes both very weak monsters and very powerful wands. While the most powerful wands cannot generate in the inventories of most early intelligent monsters, there is nothing stopping one from appearing on the ground where any such monster is free to pick it up. In the most extreme case, the [Random Number God](/wiki/Random_Number_God "Random Number God") will dispatch a [gnome](/wiki/Gnome_\(monster\) "Gnome (monster)") that came across a [wand of death](/wiki/Wand_of_death "Wand of death") – this proverbial **"gnome with the wand of death"** represents the classic [unfair death](/wiki/YASD "YASD").

## Description

[![](/images/thumb/d/d1/Gwtwod.png/400px-Gwtwod.png)](/wiki/File:Gwtwod.png)



The wrath of the RNG

The Gnome With the Wand of Death represents an existential threat to a player character that will not have found any means of defense at that point, especially in the [Gnomish Mines](/wiki/Gnomish_Mines "Gnomish Mines"). This is by no means restricted to gnomes - [hobbits](/wiki/Hobbit "Hobbit"), [goblins](/wiki/Goblin "Goblin") and [kobolds](/wiki/Kobold "Kobold") are just as capable of picking up what turns out to be a powerful wand and blasting you to death as soon as they get a turn. Even [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance") is no guarantee of safety, as it does not protect against elemental wands like the [wand of cold](/wiki/Wand_of_cold "Wand of cold") and [wand of lightning](/wiki/Wand_of_lightning "Wand of lightning").

To lessen the risk of this occurring, [pick up](/wiki/Pick_up "Pick up") any unknown wands you find on the floor and [engrave](/wiki/Engrave "Engrave")-test them to [identify](/wiki/Wand#Engrave-identification "Wand") the wands. At worst, you will identify non-threatening wands that can be put to use for other tasks. Intelligent hostile monsters such as [foocubi](/wiki/Foocubi "Foocubi"), [nymphs](/wiki/Nymph "Nymph"), and [nurses](/wiki/Nurse "Nurse") may still attack you with wands even if their normal attacks would not damage you - nymphs are particularly dangerous and capable of stealing wands from you to zap, especially on [non-teleport levels](/wiki/Non-teleport_level "Non-teleport level").

## Origin

The idea of a gnome with a wand of death has been about for some considerable time; [the first use of the joke](http://groups.google.co.uk/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/df380142b739519c) in [rgrn](/wiki/Rgrn "Rgrn") appears to have been by [Torsten Edelmann](/index.php?title=Torsten_Edelmann\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Torsten Edelmann (page does not exist)") in 1996, and it is [described as *proverbial*](http://groups.google.co.uk/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/519c9b8dc397ab4a) by 2002.

## Dudley's dungeon

In [Dudley's dungeon](/wiki/Dudley%27s_dungeon "Dudley's dungeon"), the [Gnome With the Wand of Death](/wiki/Dudley%27s_dungeon#Gnome_With_the_Wand_of_Death "Dudley's dungeon") is a recurring character that first appears in the strip for [May 31, 2005](http://www.nicolaas.net/dudley/index.php?f=20050531\&q=gnome) - here, the gnome aptly demonstrates that the "wand of death" need not be a literal one.
